tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This question requires applying concepts of buoyancy and displacement to different scenarios. It involves multiple steps of reasoning to determine the water level change in each glass, and integrates concepts from physics.

answer_validation.reasoning:
Glass P: A floating pure ice cube displaces water whose weight equals its own. When it melts, it becomes exactly that displaced water volume (since density of ice is less than water but mass is conserved). Therefore water level remains unchanged.
Glass Q: Ice cube contains a dense steel ball but the whole composite still floats (as shown). While floating, it displaces water whose weight equals the combined weight of ice + steel. After melting, the steel ball sinks to the bottom and only displaces water equal to its own volume (since submerged solid displaces volume, not weight). Because steel density is much greater than water, the volume of water displaced by the sunken ball is less than the volume of water that had been displaced due to its weight while floating. Hence the total displaced volume decreases and the water level falls.
Glass R: Ice cube contains a trapped air bubble. While floating, the composite displaces water whose weight equals ice + air. Air has negligible weight but finite volume. After melting, the air bubble escapes to the atmosphere and no longer displaces water. The melted ice alone now displaces water equal to its own volume, which is the same as in glass P. Initially, however, the floating ice with bubble had to displace slightly more water (because it had to support the small weight of the air plus the reduced average density made the cube larger for the same ice mass). Once the bubble leaves, the displaced volume reduces to that corresponding only to the melted water, so the water level decreases. Thus levels: P same, Q decreases, R decreases.

step_by_step: Identify governing principle: For floating bodies, buoyant force equals weight, so displaced water weight equals object weight. For fully submerged resting solids, displaced water volume equals object volume.

Case P (pure ice): While floating, ice displaces water of weight equal to its own. After melting, the same mass becomes liquid water of density equal to surrounding water, so its volume equals the previously displaced volume. Hence water level remains unchanged.

Case Q (ice + steel ball): While floating, the composite displaces water whose weight equals (mass of ice + mass of steel) times g. After melting, the steel ball sinks and displaces water equal only to its own (small) volume, not its weight. Since steel density is much larger than water, this displaced volume is less than what was previously required to balance its weight. The melted ice contributes the same volume as before, so total displaced volume decreases and water level drops.

Case R (ice + air bubble): The composite still floats, displacing water equal to weight of ice + air. Air has negligible weight but occupies volume inside the ice, making the average density of the cube lower and thus requiring a larger displaced volume to balance its (almost same as ice) weight. After melting, the air escapes and no longer displaces water; only the melted ice (now water) remains, which occupies the same volume as in case P. Therefore the displaced volume is less than before and the water level decreases.
Compare all three: P \u2192 same, Q \u2192 decreases, R \u2192 decreases, matching option C.

topic.name: Fluid statics and buoyancy
topic.syllabus_ref: Section 1: Aerodynamics -> Basic fluid mechanics -> Fluid statics, buoyancy

concepts.name: Phase change of water (ice to liquid)

essential: Definition of density and relation between mass, volume and density
Difference between floating and fully submerged objects
Concept of mass conservation during phase change
helpful: Typical densities of ice, water, steel and air
Understanding of free-body diagrams in statics

Main Concept: enables: Analysis of floating bodies with inclusions or cavities
enables: Design and stability assessment of marine and aerospace structures in fluids

difficulty_factors: Requires careful distinction between displacement by weight (floating) and by volume (sunk solid)
Intuition about effect of dense inclusion versus light cavity inside floating ice can be misleading

textbook_references.author: John D. Anderson
textbook_references.text_snippet: Figure 1.41: Source of the Buoyancy Force. The diagram visually explains that buoyancy is the net result of pressure being higher at the bottom of an object than at the top.

textbook_references.author: P.K. Nag
textbook_references.section: Phase change of water and density differences
textbook_references.text_snippet: A pure substance may exist in more than one phase but has uniform chemical composition, e.g., water and ice.

video_references.topic_covered: Phase diagrams and density behavior of water and ice

video_references.professor: Any standard NPTEL Fluid Mechanics course

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Use Archimedes\' principle for each configuration, compare displaced volumes before and after melting, then infer water level change.
key_insights: For pure ice, melted water volume equals previously displaced volume, so level is unchanged.
Dense inclusions that sink later reduce displaced volume compared to when they were supported by buoyancy.
Light cavities or bubbles that later escape also reduce displaced volume once they are no longer in the water.

formulas_principles.name: Buoyant force expression
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies to a body partially or fully submerged in a fluid of density $\rho_w$
formulas_principles.relevance: Relates displaced volume to buoyant force and hence to weight of floating body.

formulas_principles.name: Equilibrium of floating body
formulas_principles.conditions: Body floating at rest on a fluid surface
formulas_principles.relevance: Determines displaced volume when object floats.

formulas_principles.name: Mass-density-volume relation
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to compare volumes of ice, water, steel and air for same mass.

industry_examples: Design of ships and submarines where internal ballast (dense materials) or voids (air tanks) affect draft and displacement.
Iceberg behavior in oceans, where embedded rocks or air pockets change how much of the iceberg is submerged.
specific_systems: Buoyancy control systems in underwater vehicles using ballast tanks filled with water or air.
Fuel tanks in aircraft where trapped air bubbles can affect volume measurements but not weight.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Understanding how inclusions of different densities affect buoyancy is essential for stability and draft predictions of marine and aerospace structures interacting with fluids.

common_mistakes.mistake: Assuming that if total mass of water plus objects is unchanged, the water level must remain the same in all cases.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They conflate mass conservation with volume conservation and ignore how buoyancy changes displacement.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always think in terms of displaced volume, not just mass. Ask: Is the object floating or resting on the bottom after the change?
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to choosing options where all levels remain same or change in the same direction.

common_mistakes.mistake: Thinking that the steel ball in glass Q does not affect water level because its volume is small.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They focus on geometric size rather than the difference between displacement by weight and by volume.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Compare displaced volume when ball is supported by buoyancy (floating) versus when it sinks. Remember steel is much denser than water.
common_mistakes.consequence: Incorrectly predict no change or an increase in water level for glass Q.

common_mistakes.mistake: Assuming the air bubble in glass R will increase water level after melting because air rises.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Everyday intuition about bubbles rising is misapplied to displacement analysis.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Track whether the air is inside the water and displacing it. Once the bubble escapes to the atmosphere, it no longer displaces water.
common_mistakes.consequence: Choosing options where water level increases in glass R.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: FLOAT: Force equals LOAd (weight) displaced Totally
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: For floating bodies, displaced water weight equals object weight.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use when deciding how much water is displaced by a floating object.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: A fully sunk solid displaces water equal to its own volume, not weight.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Recall when comparing floating vs resting on bottom cases.

flashcards.front: For a floating body, what does the weight of displaced water equal?
flashcards.back: It equals the weight of the body (Archimedes\' principle: $F_b = W$).

flashcards.front: Will water level change when a pure ice cube floating in water completely melts? Why?
flashcards.back: No change. The melted water volume equals the volume of water previously displaced by the floating ice (same mass, higher density).

flashcards.front: A steel ball is frozen inside a floating ice block. After melting, ball sinks. Does water level rise, fall, or stay same?
flashcards.back: It falls. When floating, the ball caused displacement based on its weight; when sunk, it displaces only its small volume.

flashcards.front: What determines the volume of water displaced by a solid resting on the bottom of a container?
flashcards.back: Its own volume, since it is fully submerged and not supported by buoyancy alone.

flashcards.front: Mass of system is constant. Does that guarantee water level is constant? Explain briefly.
flashcards.back: No. Water level depends on displaced volume, which can change even if total mass is constant (e.g., floating vs sunk objects).

real_world_context.industry_example: Adding dense cargo or ballast water changes how deep a ship sits in water (draft) because the displaced volume must match total weight.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Incorrect prediction of draft can lead to grounding in shallow harbors or stability issues.

real_world_context.application: Icebergs carrying rocks or air pockets
real_world_context.industry_example: Icebergs with embedded rocks may float differently and pose varying collision risks to ships and offshore platforms.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Understanding buoyancy helps assess how much of an iceberg is visible above water.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Recognize as a pure buoyancy concept question with no calculations. Draw quick before/after sketches and reason about displaced volume.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If unsure, remember: pure ice melt \u2192 no change; adding heavy object that later sinks or light bubble that escapes usually reduces displacement \u2192 water level tends to decrease.
exam_strategy.time_management: Aim to finish within 2 minutes; avoid overcomplicating with numbers or equations.

search_keywords: ice cube melting water level steel ball
buoyancy displacement by weight vs volume
GATE AE fluid statics conceptual questions
ice with air bubble water level problem

alternative_methods.name: Numerical density-based comparison
alternative_methods.description: Assign approximate densities (ice 900 kg/m^3, water 1000 kg/m^3, steel 7800 kg/m^3, air ~1 kg/m^3) and a convenient mass for each component. Compute displaced volume when floating (from weight balance) and after melting/sinking (from volumes). Compare numerically to see direction of change.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Gives concrete numbers, can build strong intuition. Cons: Longer and unnecessary for exam; risk of arithmetic mistakes.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful during self-study to verify conceptual reasoning or when teaching others.

connections_to_other_subjects.Structures: Buoyancy and weight distribution affect structural loads on hulls and submerged structures.
connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Similar mass-volume-density reasoning applies to lighter-than-air vehicles like balloons and airships.
connections_to_other_subjects.Thermodynamics: Phase change of water (ice to liquid) involves density change but mass conservation, analogous to other phase-change problems.

deeper_dive_topics: Metacentric height and stability of floating bodies
Effect of salinity and temperature on water density and ship draft

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Basic fluid mechanics: Fluid statics, pressure, buoyancy
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Excellent conceptual question linking basic fluid statics with everyday phenomena; appropriate for testing deep understanding without computation.

rag_quality.notes: RAG mainly provided thermodynamics phase-diagram content and a brief mention of buoyancy figures from Anderson. Core reasoning about buoyancy and displacement for this question relied on internal fluid statics knowledge rather than RAG.

future_questions_potential: Quantitative problem: Given densities of ice, water, steel, and air, compute exact change in water level for each glass.
Extension to salt water: Compare water level changes when the same experiment is done in seawater with higher density.
Stability question: Analyze how the position of the steel ball inside the ice affects stability and tilting of the floating cube.
3D buoyancy problem: Replace glasses with a floating ship carrying cargo that is later offloaded to the seabed; compute draft change.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: The figure shows three glasses P, Q and R with water and floating ice cube. Glass P has a solid ice cube, glass Q has an ice cube with a small solid steel ball embedded in it and glass R has an ice cube with an air bubble. After the ice cube melts, the level of water in glasses P, Q and R, respectively:
